text:
GEOFFREY JONES: When did you
start investing in schools?

SANJAY BANSAL: In 1991,
we made the first school
at Ambootia state.

And it was for children
to get education free up
to the age of 12.

And that time, we had a
communist state government

who controlled primary
education, also to propagate
the political beliefs.

That aside, the
industry in Darjeeling
did not have schools.

So in fact, there was
a complaint against me

by the other [? district ?]
owners with the district

magistrate, that it is not
my job to educate the people.

And the business that
I am allowed to do
is to grow and produce tea.

So, we were called
by the administration
and asked why we are doing this.

And we said, well, we believe
that for the sustainable

future of our business, we
have to impart education

to the next generation so that
they are aware of their rights

and make better citizens
and better workers.

So, there is a little bit
of a threat at that time

we could have been
closed down by.

But luckily for us,
that didn't happen.

And we could continue
with the school.

The cost per student was
hardly 20 rupees per month.

They would get a uniform, which
included a tie, belt, cardigan,

sweater, stockings,
shoes, et cetera.

So we saw that the
demand for the children

from the other villages
also came to us.
So now we have about 36 schools.
They run on the same format.

Often the schools are
also named after some
of our clients' companies.

And this August, we'll
also for improving

the lifestyle, the
livelihood, of using money
in a more responsible manner.

And we also teach ecological
sciences to these children.

And we also educate them
on biodynamic agriculture

at the school level as
an additional subject.

And we have found that the
level of harmony in the villages
has increased tremendously.

And we have now educated
English speaking,

workers speaking tea
leaves, and doing farm work.

There hasn't been
a huge migration

which made actually
the other tea estate

owners skeptical about what
you were doing to education.

They actually [? plead ?] to
the government that people

who get educated, they will
flee and the whole industry will

have its doomsday
and it'll close down.

So this is a threat
to the existence

of the [? Darjeeling tea ?]
industry.
